cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28
R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about August 11.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9.

Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.p: Observations by Survey Department

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was a shade less warm than it has been for a few days past, but the humidity was [?]. The night was delightfully cool, and the [?] ushered in with a pleasant breeze. Barometer falling.

ADVERTISEMENTS.- P.T. 4 per line. Mi- nimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news cloumns P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisments.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English daily newspaper, established in 1880.
Editor and Manager: R Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.

div.head: AN ETHNOLOGICAL SURVEY OF THE SUDAN.
div.p: We hope that as soon as the necessary funds are forthcoming, the Sudan Govern ment will be able to undertake a thorough ethnological survey of the enormous terri tories under its rule, from Wady Halfa to Gondokoro and from Suakin to the Darfour frontier. The Sudan, be it remembered, is peopled by races belonging to almost all the chief stocks of Northern Africa, and a mul titude of half-bred stocks sprung from the mixture, in centres like Omdurman, of olmost every race in the Near East.

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: When SUNLIGHT SOAP is in the tub,
You needn't boil, nor toil, nor scrub;
Just try it the SUNLIGHT Way,
A whole wash done in half a day.
Soap

In the North there are the desert Arabs, the Bishareen-a totally distinct race-and the Nubians and Barabra, whose origin and ethnic affinities are so little known that while some authorities assert that they are distant kinsmen of the lightcoloured Foula or Fulbe of the Niger, others, among them the German Ranke, group them, as far as their physical characteristics go, with the "Dravidian" (Tamil-speaking) races of Southern India. In the East are Arabs, Hadendowa (who are Beja speakers among themselves, akin to the Bishareen on one side and the Danskil and Somali on the other) and there are a multitude of little known races-Abyssinian, Arab, Bishareen, and Negro, interbred and mixed, who dwell along the Abyssinian frontier between Kassala and the Blue Nile. Kordofan contains Arabs, Negroes, and Nubians, and to the South there are Negro tribes of every shade, from the pale-faced Berta to the jet-black Shilluck, some forming what scientists call the "Nilotic" group, others, such as the redoubtable A-Zandeh or Niam Niam, more akin to the brown races of the Congo forest, and others, such as the Latuka and Bari, related and not so distantly related to the Massai of East Africa and their kindred tribes. A variety of dialects and lan guages, not all of which have received the attention of scientific philologists, are spoken by these peoples. their manners and customs, however strange and repulsive, have a fscinat ing interest to the student and their religion and their folk-lore, their tribal ceremonies, and their festal dances should all be recorded before it is too late. We are ready to admit that these are by no means dying races; they are, on the contrary, vigorous and prolific enough, but the very settlement of the Sudan, the introduction of law and order, the end of raiding and slave-hunting are certain, in time, to efface the differences in customs and institu tions that centuries of strife and seclusion have brought about.

We do not regret that this should be so. It is no doubt an excellent thing for a Dinka to become a Moslem, learn some Arabic, avoid intoxicants and tribal corroborees, lose some of his belief in witchcraft, and make an honest living. But before the tribe fol lows the example of our hypothetical Dinka, let every fact of the least importance concern ing its manners and customs, its traditions and its ritual, be preserved. There can be little doubt that the spread of the Pax Britannica in the Sudan will be accompanied by an extension of the domain of the Arabic language and, very probably, by the advance of Islam, which, whether spread by peaceful means or by the sword, has a strange attraction for the black races. Even among the outlying tribes, foreign influences will effect their beliefs and even their traditions-have not German scientists recorded their horror when Papuans, who had been to mission schools before reverting to cannibalism in the bush, mingled with their mythological tales of Lot's wife and the Garden of Eden-trade goods will replace articles manu factured by the tribe: the more barbarous or licentious elements in their rites will be jealously concealed and if they do not gradually die out, will be greatly toned down and slowly effaced, to the great advantage of morals and the ill-concealed chagrin of inquiring scientists. And among savages, be it remembered, these changes operate very rapidly.

row.cell: The sun in Leo. The interior of the earth is cooled
Grapes and figs in full season.
It is good to take cold baths.
Clothes must not be washed for seven days. Chicory sown.
Good season for marriages. Mustard seed gathered.

div.head: ENGLISH PENSION, ITALIAN RIVIERA.
div.p: The best halfway home between Egypt and England is VIAREGGIO. near PISA.
Main line expresses stop. Fine woods, Sands, Sea bathing mild climate, English Pension, Villa Shelly. Ever home comfort. Electric light. Modern sanitation, Sunny aspect, close to sea and gardens.
Proprietress. English Ladies

div.head:
IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.
GOVERNMENT DEFEAT.
MINISTRY NOT TO RESIGN.

div.p: HOUSE OF COMMONS.-In the Committee of Supply, Mr. Redomond protested against the way in which the Land Act is administered. He moved a reduction in the vote for the Land Commission. The motion was carried by 199 to 196. There was prolonged excitement, the opposition shouting exultingly.

In reply to Sir. H. Campbell-Bannerman Mr. Balfourdeclined at present to state the Government's intentions in view of the defeat. He will do so on Monday, aftert consulting his colleagues Previous Governments, when de [?] votes of estimates, have often asked [?] to reverse the vote. This was only [?]rtunate accident, and there will be [?] opportunity of proving whether the Government enjoys the confidence of the House, as Monday is the day fixed for the discussion of the vote of censure proposed by Sir. E. Grey. The Opposition left the House shouting at the top of their voices.
The Unionist organs consider it unlikely that the Government will place a grave construction on the vote.
(Reuter.)

The Cabinet meets to-day and to-morrow. The House of Commons rushed through the Scotch Churches Bill this morning, and then adjourned. The lobbies swarmed with excited members with a marked disposition to regard the defeat seriously.
(Reuter.)
It is believed that the Cabinet will come to no decision before Monday.
(Reuter.)

Mr. Balfour, in a short audience with the King yesterday evening, informed his Majesty that he and his colleagues are agreed that the circumstances do not make it incumbent upon the Cabinet to resign. Most papers now believe that Mr. Balfour will propose the rescission of Thursday's vote, wind up the session, and dissolve in the autumn.
(Reuter.)

The Japanese ships are increasingly active. They have appeared at Pachkevitch Bay, to the south of Vladivostok, and at Kriniloff Bay and Anna Bay, at the mouth of the Amur. The cruisers are bombarding the townships, and the inhabitants of Vladivostok and Niko laievskare fleeing inland.
(Reuter.)
M. Witte has arrived.
M. Rouvier will receive M. Witte, Russian peace plenipotentiary, to-morrow.
(Havas.)
Mayor Seattle met Mr. Komura and his staff on the pier and conducted them to a special train. The railway magnate Mr. Hill placed his own car at their disposal for the journey to Washington.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
TSAR AND KAISER.
IMPENDING MEETING OF SOVEREIGNS.

div.p: Persistent reports here and at St. Petersburg would imply an impending meeting of the Emperor and the Tsar, on the coast of Sweden.
(Reuter.)
It is rumoured that the Tsar and Emperor William will meet each other in the Baltic.
(Havas.)
The Congress of the Zemstvos lengthily discussed the model constitution.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
TERRIBLE BOILER EXPLOSION.
CRUISER BLOWN UP.

div.p: A terrible boiler explosion has taken place on the small cruiser Bennington. The greater part of the deck was blown into the air. There are twenty-seven killed and seventy injured.
(Reuter.)
Eclipse Stakes. 1, Val d'Or; 2, Cicero; 3 Llangibly.
(Reuter.)
Derbyshire beat Northamptonshire by an innings and 50 runs.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
OUTRAGE ON SULTAN.
FATAL BOMB EXPLOSION.
FORTY OF ENTOURAGE KILLED.

div.p: During the Selamlik a bomb exploded in the courtyard of the mosque near the Sultan, who was not touched. Several of his entourage were either killed or wounded. Numerous arrests were made.
(Havas.)

(Official). As the Sultan was leaving the mosque after the Selamlik a bomb exploded in the courtyard. There are several killed and wounded, but his Majesty is unhurt. He dis played his usual composure and courage, and drove back to the palace, bowing to the people as if nothing had happened. Unofficial reports state that there were 40 killed.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE PLAGUE.-
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin only records one case, at Alexandria.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS
div.p: found in the Boulac district of Cairo during the night of Monday and at daybreak on Tuesday will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: COLLAPSE OF ROOF.-
div.p: A roof collapsed in the Gabbari quarter yesterday, inflicting in juries on an Arab woman named Amma She hata, which necessitate 25 days' medical treatment.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: -13 vessels passed through the Canal on the 19th inst., 8 of which were British, 3 German, 2 Austrian. The day's receipts were frs. 385,183.03, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 5,521,228.88.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.-
div.p: This evening the French comedy company will produce Le Paradis. A matinée performance will be given to-morrow of Mme Mongodin, and in the evening Monsieur Chasse will be staged.

div.head: TANTAH WATER COMPANY.-
div.p: We have receiv ed a copy of the report of the ordinary and extraordinary general meetings of the Tantah Water Company which took place on February 28th 1905. To the report is appended the financial state of the company at the close of 1904.

div.head: LOCAL COMMISSIONS.-
div.p: We hear that a Local Commission may be formed at Zagazig on the same lines as thouse of Fayoum, Mansourah, and Tantah. The establishment of Local Com missions at Beni-Souef and Minieh is also under consideration at the Ministry of the Interior.

div.head: COAL IMPORTS.-
div.p: From the 1st of January to the 20th July, 492,929 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 282,604, Newcastle 97,201, Scotland 66,880, Yorkshire 26, 876, and other places 19,368 tons. During the same period last year 539,110 tons were received.

div.head: A FIRE
div.p: broke out in a house in the Labbane quarter about 8 o'clock this morning. The Fire Brigade were soon on the spot but as the house was made of wood, it was partially gutted in a very short time. The efforts of the firemen were mainly directed to saving the laves of the in habitants and circumscribing the conflagration, which was finally extinguished about 11 o'clock.

div.head: PRIZE DISTRIBUTION.-
div.p: The annual distri bution of prizes at the Externat St. Joseph, conducted by the Sisters of St. Vincent de Paul, Moharrem Bey, takes place this after noon, under the presidency of M. C. Coury, superior of the Lazarists. A very attractive programme has been arranged for the delecta tion of parents and friends of the scholars. It includes a historical drama in 5 acts, entitled Marie de Brabant.

div.head: WE HAVE PLEASURE
div.p: in calling the attention of our readers to the last report and balance sheet of the Union Discount Company of London, Limited, which appears in our columns to-day. This company is one of the most important institutions doing a large and pros perous business in the London Money Market. The company discounts first-class bank and mercantile paper, grants loans on approved negotiable securities, and takes money on deposit on the terms current in London for the time being. We understand they are doing a considerable business in this country.

div.head: ABSTRACT IDEAS.-
div.p: Many people imagine that the Berlitz Method is only a series of object-lessons. It would be impossible to teach abstract words in this manner. For these, the method of associating ideas, or of explaining ideas, or of explaining by the context, is used. In the same way as in an algebraical equation the unkown quantity is found by its connec tion with the known quantities, so the con catenation of ideas, the evident relation between the new expression and the words already learned, makes it easily understood. Naturally only experienced teachers possess this true science of teaching. This is the case in the Berlitz Schools at Cairo and in Alexandria.

div.head: NEW SYSTEM OF ARTESIAN WELL.-
div.p: Mr. G. N. Perrakis of Alexandria has invented a new system of artesian well superior to any other system, owing to its perfection and the power of resistance, being constructed with the best material and capable of increasing instead of decreasing the supply of water. One of the kind was constructed on the estate of Messrs. N. and A. Sursock, and has been patented to avoid imitations. Mr. Perrakis has procured special tools for boring and digging earth of any kind, above 2,000 feet. For hitherto uncultivated lands he accepts the value of the work in land. He has a stock of steam engines, mills, ice-making machines, aerated water plant, tambours (Archimedean screws), sakkiehs, weighing-machines, pumps and accessories, etc. Repairs of machinery also undertaken.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.
A REPLY BY "TRAFFIC."
div.p: I am sorry that ill health and press of work have prevented my replying sooner to the remarks the Editor has been good enough to make with reference to my comments upon the report of Lord Farrer's Commission. I had fancied that I had let his lordship off very lightly, but apparently the Editor of the "Gazette" does not take that view of my comments. Personally, I have, of course, no other interest in the matter than that of one of the public, except that, as one has had to study the question of the administration of railways, [?] to their financial and their practical working, I could not help being surprised at the report. What was really wanted, it seems to me, was not a series of general statements and suggestions, but a clearly defined, comprehensive, and, above all, a throroughly practical scheme for the admi nistration of the State Railways, and this, I submit, is exactly what the Commission has not supplied.

There is no special mystery in the admi nistration of a railway. This, it is true, requires for its consideration special knowledge, but not more so than any other business or pro fession. A railway company is nothing more than a commercial undertaking to supply a public need, and stands therefore to the public in the same relation as the baker, draper, or banker. If, therefore, it is to be run success fully, it must be run with the same consi deration for the principles of commerce and trade as regulates all other businesses, and with a sufficient knowledge of the practical working of the organisation necessary for the attainment of its object. Just as it is for the baker to consider how he can most cheaply produce the bread and other food-stuffs he undertakes to deal in, and how he can enlarge his field by the acquisition of new customers, so exactly is it the business of the railway company to study how it can provide the community it deals in-the transport of passengers and goods in the cheapest and most effective way that will be at once bene ficial to itself and to the public. The fact of a railway being run as a Government Depart ment makes no other difference than that it justifies the proprietor (the Government) in giving special prominence to his own share of the sum total of advantages to be derived from the undertaking.

Now, [?] being so, and I cannot conceive anyone being inclined to dispute it, there is and can be no reason why any man of sufficient practical knowledge and experience, when placed in possession of the necessary details, cannot draw up a clearly defined and business- like scheme for the administration of any rail way in any part of the world. Railways in Egypt are run for precisely the same reasons that they are run in England, and the conditions that make successful working in the one country are those that make it in the other, for while it is of course essential that local conditions be considered, these do not affect the principles involved, but merely their application.

It would be tedious and, I fear, very unprofitable to go through the Report and show how on every page it utterly ignores these facts and instead of laying down broad guiding lines, clearly set out, gives doubtful and hesitating advice on matters of detail that the Commis sion admits it had no time or opportunity of studying sufficiently. Let any really practical man compare the scheme of Departments that I give in my letter with the hazy suggestion of the Commission on page five of its report, and I have not the least fear that his verdict will be adverse to me. As I said, two or more of the Departments may, at times, be con veniently amalgamated as the Locomotive and Carriage Departments are on the State Rail ways, while others, such as the Electrical and Signalling, though nominally united, from the irresistable force of their inherent independence, inevitably becomes seperate and seperately working Departments.

The fact is that in all railway work the one really and only absolutely indispensable head is the Traffic Manager. Without him all the work of the Permanent Way, of the Signalling, and all the other branches of the work must come to a standstill, while in the case of small local lines he may easily replace each and all of the other heads. IF it be necessary to give any proof of this, it is to be found in the number of instances in which railway companies in England and elsewhere have running powers on the lines of other companies, in which cases all the work of the company is dones, so far as those lines are concerned, by the Traffic Manager, the construction and maintenance of the lines, stations, signalling, etc., etc., being carried out entirely and solely by the company owning the line. It follows that the Permanent Way, the Signalling, the Locomotive, and other departments of the administration, might be worked by independent contractors carrying out the instructions of the Traffic Manager. Hence the position that my scheme gives the Traffic Manager is the one that he really holds or should hold, and indeed always will hold, in spite of all the theories or of fantastic nominal divisions of the administration.
(To be continued)

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The Following is the programme of to-morrow morning's vocal and instrumental concert:-

row.cell: Solo di Cavanalossi[?], "E lucevan le stelle"
Signa. M. Cantoni. Sig. G. Giovanelli. Sig. S. Greggio.

div.p: The Bracale orchestra will accompany the artistes and will play between the different items.

div.head: BLUE NILE EXPLORATION.
MR. MACMILLAN'S EXPEDITION.
div.p: Mr. W. Macmillan,who has already rendered conspicuous services to geographical science by his explorations on the Upper Nile and else where, projects a seconds expedition along the course of the Blue Nile, to commence about April next. His object is to establish a com mercial route between Abyssinia and the Southern Sudan, which shall ,as far as pos sible, be a river way. According to present intentions, Mr. Macmillan will arrive in Egypt in a month or two to make his final arrange ments.

Mr. Macmillan is an American, and is con vinced that the Blue Nile offers a solution to the many questions which confront those who seek the commercial development of the part of Africa in which he has interested himself. For the purpose of navigation, he has caused to be built in Norway several wooden boats or barges, of the kind used on the western coast of that country for transport among the fjords, boats which have been specially fashioned for passage through the rapids.

These boats are to travel via London to Khartoum, and are of two sizes-the one about twenty feet in length, the other larger by ten feet. They are double-ended and cleaver built, with light draft, and the uprights supporting the outer planking are of an unusual solidity. They have what is known as a deck-strake that is to say, it will only be necessary to lay down thwartship planking to deck or half-deck the craft, and while, in still waters, a large single sail-standing lug or lateen-will furnish an ample motive power, they are shallow enough to be towed or poled.

The section boats, generally of light steel, with which explorers in the past have equipped themsleves, offer the advantage of a boat easily portable where a waterway is broken by rapids or otherwise. But they go no way towards solving the problem of a stream's general capa city for a water borne trade. Mr. Macmillan's craft, however, will carry the baggage of the expedition, and it is intended to haul them bodily up the rapids, a feat which by no means lacks a precedent, notably during the last Egyptian campaign on the advance to Omdurman.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
IMPORTANT DECISIONS.
div.p: The following were the decisions of the Council of Ministers which met yesterday at San Stefano:-
1. H.E. Mazloum Pasha to act as Minister of War during the absence on leave of H.E. Abani Pasha.
Mr. Dunlop to act as Under Secretary of State to the Ministry of Public Instruction during the absence on leave of H.E. Yacoub Pasha Artin.

3. Mr. Verschoyle, while retaining his func tions as the Inspector General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt to act as Inspector General of Irrigation in Upper Egypt during the absence on leave of Mr. Clowes.

4. The Budget of the Ministry of Public Instruction for 1906 is increased by L.E. 40,000, bringing its total to L.E. 274,800, with a view to the further development of primary, secondary, and higher education in Egypt, to improve the condition of the personnel.
5. A new credit of L.E. 10,000 is to be opened for the necessary precautionary mea sures against plague and bovine typhus.
6. A new credit of L.E. 5,000 is to be opened to continue the campaign against the cotton worm.
7. A further extension of the Cairo tram ways is sanctioned.
8. The street between the Abou el Ela Mosque and the Technical, Boulac, is to be widened with a view to allowing a tramline to be taken past the National Printing Office.
9. The construction of a station by the Delta Light Railway Company at Aga (Mit Ghamr Mansourah line) is sanctioned.
10. An irrigation rest-house to be construc ted at Dessouk, Gharbieh.

Other decisions refer to the construction of a branch of the Sharanah Canal, at Belkas village, Gharbieh, and to the exemption from stamp duties and transfer of property tax granted to the "Congregation de la Mère de Dieu," which has recently acquired a property at Ghizieh.

div.head: THE OM NABARDI MINE.
div.p: Lord Ribblesdale at the "Mysore" meet ing referred to the company's holding in the Sudan Gold Field Company, and, amongst other things, said that the Om Nabardi mine, to which special attention has up to the pre sent been directed, is being actively developed. This mine is thought well of by the managers and by Mr. Arthur Llewellyn, the superintend ing engineer in the Sudan. The block being worked comprises a length of 3,000 ft. along the run of the reef, and in some cases the shafts have reached a depth of 200 ft.

Upon the reefs drivages aggregating 2,200 [?] have been made, and length of auriferous stone of high value have been continuously traced, in many instances the panning results going up to 3 to 4 ozs. to the ton.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Persian Prince left Malta yesterday for Tripoli, Barbary, and is due here on Tues day with general cargo from Antwerp and London.
The Moss liner Menes arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: BOUND FOR MALTA
div.p: The British India S.S. Fazilka, on a voyage from London to Calcutta, arrived here at dawn to-day and reported having passed the four British battleships which left Port Said on Wednesday steering for Malta, some 180 miles W.N.W. of Damietta. The Ocean was towing the Vengeance and the ships appeared to be making about 10 knots.

div.head: THE AIDA
div.p: H.H.S. Aida arrived from Alexandria at noon to-day bound for the Red Sea light houses. She is at present anchored at the War Department buoys and is to enter the canal at dawn to-morrow.

div.head: THE PASSENGER JETTIES.
div.p: The first step towards the improvement in the passenger jetties has been taken and a particularly filthy café has been shut down, permission having been granted the pro prietors to build another on a piece of land close to the north end of the bridge leading to the Custom House jetties. This permission appears to have been given without consulting the Canal Company, and we have in conse quence the pleasure of seeing, at a corner of one of the principal thoroughfares, skeleton frameworks, stones, cement, and all the build ing paraphernalia, and no movement towards completion or removal of débris,-the frequent result of "Government activity" in the wrong direction.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: M. Beau, Governor-General of Indo-China, arrived at Suez by the Messageries Maritimes steamer Caledonien yesterday morning. His Excellency was met on board by M. Altemer, French Vice-Consul at Suez, with whom he afterwards visited the French Hospital. M. Beau left by the 8 a.m. train for Cairo, where he will make a short stay, and then proceed to France.

We hear that Mohamed Bey Saleh, President of the Assiout Court, has withdrawn his com plaint against Ali Bey Abou el Futuh and the counsel of Bedawi Bey Riffahi, in which he alleged that they had used defamatory and abusive language concerning him and the other members of the Assiout Native Court during the hearing of the Riffahi case.
Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of the Cairo City Police, goes on leave to-day and, accom panied by Mrs. Mansfield, is proceeding to Europe.

The Following visitors are staying at the Beau Rivage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr. G.D. Horn blower, Mr. and Mrs. W. Page, Mr. S.G. Henein, Mr. and Mrs. J. Press and family, Mr. and Mrs. Marc Matatia, Miss L. Stevens, Mr. and Mrs. H. Daffa and family, Mr. E. Klein, Cav. and Mme. Ugo Luzzatto and family, Mr. and Mrs. Nicolas Bey Boustros, Mr. and Mrs. L. Zoucas and family, Mr. and Mrs. J. David. Mr. and Mrs. E. Barozzi and family, Mr. and Mrs. H. Hensey, Mr. and Mr.s P. Papazian, Mr. R. Pearl, Mr. and Mrs. Y.C. Schreiber, Mr. and Mrs.. L. Pally and family, Mr. and Mrs. P. Hambartzum, Miss L. Isler, Miss M. Daring, Mme. Virginia de Castro, Mme. M. Korsonsky and family.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: The following is the programme of the Gym khana to be held on the A.S.C. grounds on Saturday, 29th inst., commencing at 3.30 p.m.

div.head: 1st EVENT.
div.p: BENDING RACE.-Competitors to ride in heats their ponies in and out a row of flags, turning round the end one and returning the same way. Entrance P.T. 10. Prize, pbjet d'art.

div.head: 2nd EVENT.
div.p: POSTILLION RACE.-Each Competitor to ride 200 yards leading a bareback pony, dismount, change the saddle to the other pony and gallop back to winning post, leading the unsaddled pony. Entrance P.T. 10. Prize, objet d'art.

div.head: 3rd EVENT.
div.p: MATHEMATICAL STAKES.-Gentlemen to ride from the distance post over a hurdle and give a piece of paper with a sum on it to a lady. Lady writes down the answer and gentleman gallops round the post and over the hurdle to the winning post. First in with correct answer wins. Entrance nil. Prize to the lady, objet d'art.

div.head: 4th EVENT.
div.p: CAPTIVITY STAKES.-Lady to ride bicycle 100 yards, dismount, tie a riband round the arm of her gentleman, who will be waiting for her, and then remount and ride home leading him by the riband. Entrance nil. Prize, objet d'art.

div.head: 5th EVENT.
div.p: MOTOR CAR BE[?]DING RACE.-Competitors to drive their cars in and out a row of flags turning round the end one and returning the same way. Quickest time wins after deduc tion of points for touching any post. En trance P.T. 10. Prize, objet d'art.

div.head: 6th EVENT.
div.p: LLOYD LINDSAY-TEAMS OF FOUR. To ride over a hurdle from 200 yards distance. Two hold the ponies and two dismount and knock a row of bottles off a table with potatoes. Remount and ride round the distance post back over the hurdle. Quickest time wins. Entrance P.T. 20 per team. Prize, objet d'art.

div.head: 7th EVENT.
div.p: APPLE RACE.-Each Competitor to start at the distance post ride over a hurdle to in front of the Grand Stand, catch 3 apples thrown to him by a lady, and gallop back round the post and over the hurdle to the winning post. First past the winning post with 3 apples wins. En trance nil. Prize to the lady, objet d'art.
Post entries for all events. Entrance fees to be paid at time of entry.
Ponies and motor cars must be ridden and driven by members of the Club.
Prizes cannot be changed.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Le calme le plus absolu régnait au début de cette semaine, lorsque des liasses de titres ayant passé de main trop faibles en des porte feuiles plus solides un réveil s'est produit qui nous a fait clôture en reprise, avec de nom breuses affaires. La création du Comptoir Fi nancier et Commercial n'est pas étrangère à ce relèvement: notre marché a tellement souffert jusqu'ici de l'exaggération des reports pour les meilleures valeurs et de leur taux scandaleux pour les titres moins recherchés que le prochain lancement de cette société nouvelle a été salué par tous comme un bienfait et une sauvegard contre de nouveaux abus. Il convient, cepend ant, de noter que la faveur de la spéculation tend de plus en plus à délaisser les petites valeurs nouvellement émises pour s'attacher aux anciennes qui présentent à son avis plus de sécurité.

Le groupe des Hôtels est actuellement à l'ordre du jour et, si l'état sanitaire se main tient indemne, la saison promet d'être brillante. Quant à l'Anglo-American Nile, le prochain établissement de la Compagnie concurrente, Hamburg America Linie, rembrunit pour elle l'horizon, mais on croit savoir dans certains milieux qu'une entente aurait lieu entre les deux compagnies. En tous cas l'Anglo-Ameri can n'a pas de concurrence à redouter avant la saison 1906-1907. Toujours à propos de navigation, on annonce le prochain lancement de la Delta and Upper Nile Navigation Co. qui s'occuperait exclusivement du transport des merchandises. Le capital de cette société est fixé à 40.000 Livres, divisé en 10.000 actions de 4 livres chacune. Un groupe de négociants grecs de notre ville a déjà souscrit la totalité de ces actions.

Après avoir été la plus recherché des va leurs, la Daïra se trouve aujourd'hui la plus délaissée. Les détenteurs faibles commence ment à s'impatienter de ne rien savoir encore de précis touchant la liquidation. Diverses affaires restent en suspens, entre autres deux ou trois procès, dont le plus important a été réglé à l'amiable cette semaine, au Caire. Comme d'ici à fin octobre les intérêtes à payer, ajoutés au prix coûtant, ne leur permettent d'envisager qu'un bénéfice peu appréciable, ces détenteurs préfèrent liquider pour se lancer sur d'autres titres, pour lesquels ils entrevoient une hausse plus assurée. Ce sont, bien entendu, les gros capitalistes qui profitent de la situa tion.

Il y a eu de la reprise sure les Banques, en particulier sur la National, l'Agricole et la Banque d'Athènes. Les valeurs à traction, les Tramways surtout, ont donné lieu à d'import antes transactions. Quant aux valeurs foncières, elles demeurent délaissées en dépit d'une excellente récolte et du maintien des prix.

De 13 13/16 l'Agricole monte à 14 pour clô turer à 13 15/16 acheteurs. La nouvelle fléchit de 9 9/16 à 9 7/16 pour reprendre à 9 19/32 en La Fondateur, qui avait clôturé la semaine dernière à 975, touche un moment le cours de 1040 pour finir à 1020 nominal.

La National Bank fléchit de 26 5/16 à 26 7/32, mais reprend en clôture à 26 1/2 acheteurs. La nouvelle clôture également à 26 1/2. A un moment donné, l'écart était de 1/8 en faveur de l'action ancienne, mais la totalité des titres nouveaux n'étant pas encore livrée et le montant à verser pour ceux-ci était encore de 15 £ inférieur au prix à verser pour l'ancienne, les spéculateurs ont réussi à maintenir les prix au même niveau.
La Land Bank débute à 9 1/4, atteint 9 7/16 et clôture acheteurs à 9 3/8.
La Cassa di Sconto monte de 177 à 182 pour revenir à 178.
Très soutenue et très animée, la Banque d'Athènes ouvre à 124 pour hausser graduel lement jusqu'à 128 1/2. A Paris la cote marque 130.
Après avoir fluctué toute la semaine entre 815 et 816, l'action Crédit Foncier clôture à 820 acheteurs.
La Daïra fléchit de 28 1/8 à 27 7/8 pour reprendre en clôture à 28 1/16. La Deferred reste immobile entre 179 et 180.
Faible au début à 12 7/8, la Delta Light se raffermit vers la fin à 13 acheteurs. La Deferred fléchit de 14 à 13 1/2.

Les Privilegiée Tramways d'Alexandrie haus sent de 164 1/4 à 166 pour retomber en clô ture à 162 à la suite d'importantes réalisa tions. Les Dividiennes montent également de 340 à 347 pour réactionner à 345.
De 4 3/8 l'Urbino fléchit à 4 17/32 pour finir acheteurs à 4 5/8.
L'Investement sommeille entre 1 11/32 et 1 3/8.
Une grande animation a régné sur le Trust qui fluctue en 1 3/8 et 1 15/32 pour finir à 1 3/8.

Le rapport préliminaire des Estates a pro duit sur le public une excellente impression. Les administrateurs y déclarent qu'ils préfèrent employer l'argent disponible à des prêts sur hypothèques, source de revenus considérables et immédiats, que de l'engager en spéculat ions hasardeuses sur des terrains dont la valeur semble avoir subi récemment une poussée artificielle. En tous cas, de meilleurs occasions ne peuvent manquer de se présenter. Le cours, après avoir fléchi à 27/32, s'est raffermi à 7/8 en forte demande à la suite du rapport en question.
De 1115 les Eaux du Caire haussent à 1135 acheteurs. La frigonifique monte également de 4 15/16 à 5 1/8 acheteurs.
De 9 7/16 la Nungovich arrive d'emblée à 9 7/8 acheteurs sans qu'il se présente de ven deurs sérieux même à des cours plus élevés. On escompte une forte hausse.
Les Egyptian Hotels (Baehler) montent de 2 3/16 à 2 1/4 acheteurs. Les Upper Egypt Hotels haussent également de 4 7/16 à 4 5/8 et les Splendid Hotels de 4 3/16 à 4 1/4.
L'Anglo-American Nile ouvre à 5 3/8, flé chit à 5 5/16 et clôture acheteurs à 5 3/8.
L'Oasis hausse graduellement de 15/16 jus qu'à 1 1/8. Cette valeur se trouve actuellement en grande faveur à Londres au cours de 1 1/2 (l'action nominative).

Peu d'affaires en Brasseries. La Crown Brewery Priviligiée reste immobile entre 200 et 202 pendant que la Dividende monte de 103 à 110 acheteurs. La Brasserie des Pyramides est calme entre 110 et 112 la Privilégíée et à 60 la Dividende.
Les Ciments d'Egypte haussent de 69 à 75 la Privilégiée et de 15 à 18 la Dividende.

D'importantes transactions ont eu lieu en Comptoir, dont le cours a débuté à 4 1/4, at teint 4 5/8 et clôture à 4 15/32. La Fondateur est peu traitée; on l'évalue de 30 à 40 Livres. Les résultats des souscriptions sont échangée en grande quantité avec 1/4 et 3/8 de prime. Le dernier cours pour résultat a été de 9/32 de prime.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
BULLETIN HEBDOMADAIRE
div.p: Alexandrie, VENDREDI à Midi le 14 Juillet 1905

row.cell: Pour les Feves, Orges, Bles, Lentilles, Mais et Oignons, la consommation locale n'est connue respectivement que les 31 Mars et 24 Novembre
N.B.– L'année pour les Blés et les Lentilles commence au 1er Avril, pour les Mais le 1er Décembre, pour les Oignons le 1er Mars.
COTON SUIVANT LES TYPES DE L'ASSOCIATION
Marché des Cotons: ferme, bonne demande.
